@metadata.goal: The student can express equal parts using unit fraction notation

steps.dialogue: Here are four bars. Each one is divided differently, and some have shaded parts.
Find all the bars that show the same unit fraction. Remember, a unit fraction has 1 as the numerator.

prompt.text: Select all bars showing the same unit fraction

step.dialogue: Check which bars have exactly one part shaded out of the total.

events.name: pulse_shaded_bar_a
events.description: Shaded section in Bar A pulses to draw attention

events.name: pulse_shaded_bar_c
events.description: Shaded section in Bar C pulses to draw attention

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_shaded_bar_a][event:pulse_shaded_bar_c]Let's think about this together. A unit fraction has 1 shaded part. Count the shaded parts in each bar and check the total parts.

events.name: label_fraction_bar_a
events.description: Overlay displays '1/4' label next to Bar A with annotation showing 1 shaded, 4 total

events.name: label_fraction_bar_b
events.description: Overlay displays '1/8' label next to Bar B with annotation showing 1 shaded, 8 total

events.name: label_fraction_bar_c
events.description: Overlay displays '1/4' label next to Bar C with annotation showing 1 shaded, 4 total

events.name: label_fraction_bar_d
events.description: Overlay displays '2/4' label next to Bar D with annotation showing 2 shaded, 4 total

step.dialogue: [event:label_fraction_bar_a][event:label_fraction_bar_b][event:label_fraction_bar_c][event:label_fraction_bar_d]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. Bar A has 1 shaded out of 4 total—that's [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. Bar B has 1 shaded out of 8—that's [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction]. Bar C has 1 shaded out of 4—that's [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. Bar D has 2 shaded out of 4—that's [fraction numerator=2 denominator=4]two fourths[/fraction], not a unit fraction. Bars A and C both show [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. See how that works?

on_correct.dialogue: You got it. Both bars show [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction], even though different parts are shaded.

@metadata.goal: The student can count the total number of equal parts in a whole

steps.dialogue: Here are two bars showing different fractions. Bar A shows [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction] and Bar B shows [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction].
Count all the equal parts in each whole bar. Which bar has more parts, and how many more?

options: Both have the same number of parts

step.dialogue: Count the total parts in each bar carefully.

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_a
events.description: Each section in Bar A pulses sequentially to support counting

events.name: pulse_sections_bar_b
events.description: Each section in Bar B pulses sequentially to support counting

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_sections_bar_a][event:pulse_sections_bar_b]Let's think about this together. Count all the sections in Bar A, then all the sections in Bar B. Which has more?

events.name: overlay_counting_sequence_bar_a
events.description: Animated overlay showing numbers 1-6 appearing sequentially above each section in Bar A

events.name: overlay_counting_sequence_bar_b
events.description: Animated overlay showing numbers 1-4 appearing sequentially above each section in Bar B

events.name: show_total_label_bar_a
events.description: Label '6 parts' appears next to Bar A

events.name: show_total_label_bar_b
events.description: Label '4 parts' appears next to Bar B

step.dialogue: [event:overlay_counting_sequence_bar_a][event:overlay_counting_sequence_bar_b][event:show_total_label_bar_a][event:show_total_label_bar_b]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. Count Bar A's sections: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. That's 6 parts. Now Bar B: 1, 2, 3, 4. That's 4 parts. So Bar A has 2 more parts than Bar B. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: You counted both wholes and found the difference. That's solid comparison work.

@metadata.goal: The student can identify and maintain the whole when working with unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Two students each have a bar divided into thirds. Look closely at their bars.
Each student shaded [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction] of their bar. But notice the bars are different sizes.
Could these two [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one thirds[/fraction] represent different amounts? Think about the size of each whole.

options: True - They could be different amounts
False - One-third is always the same amount

step.dialogue: Look at the size of each whole bar. Does that matter?

events.name: highlight_shaded_section
events.description: The shaded 1/3 sections of both bars pulse to show their sizes

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_shaded_section]You're working on it. Compare the actual size of the shaded parts. Even though both are labeled [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction], look at how much space each takes up.

events.name: measure_whole_then_part
events.description: Animated overlay measures the full bars, then highlights and measures the 1/3 shaded sections

events.name: compare_shaded_amounts
events.description: Visual comparison showing Student 1's 1/3 is physically larger than Student 2's 1/3

step.dialogue: [event:measure_whole_then_part][event:compare_shaded_amounts]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. Both students have [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction], but look at the wholes. Student 1's whole bar is much bigger, so [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction] of it is a larger amount. Student 2's whole bar is smaller, so [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction] of it is a smaller amount. The fraction depends on the size of the whole. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: Exactly right. The fraction depends on the whole – different wholes, different amounts.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here are two bars showing unit fractions. Bar A shows [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction], and Bar B shows [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction].
A student says: 'Unit fractions with bigger denominators are bigger because bigger numbers are always bigger.' Look at the shaded parts carefully.
Is the student's reasoning correct? Compare the actual sizes of the shaded parts.

options: True - Bigger denominators make bigger fractions
False - Bigger denominators make smaller unit fractions

step.dialogue: Look at the actual size of each shaded piece.

events.name: pulse_shaded_section
events.description: The shaded sections in both bars pulse to draw attention to their sizes

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_shaded_section]You're working on it. Compare the shaded parts visually - which piece takes up more space on the bar?

events.name: measure_section_width
events.description: Animated measurement overlays showing the width of one section in each bar

events.name: comparison_arrow_larger
events.description: Arrow annotation indicating Bar A's section is larger

step.dialogue: [event:measure_section_width][event:comparison_arrow_larger]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. Look at Bar A - it's divided into 3 parts, so each piece is pretty big. Bar B is divided into 8 parts, so each piece is much smaller. The reasoning is false because bigger denominators make smaller unit fractions. See how that works?

on_correct.dialogue: Exactly right. You saw that [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction] is smaller than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction], even though 8 is bigger than 3.

@metadata.goal: The student can apply partitioning strategies and recognize patterns with equal parts

steps.dialogue: Here's Bar A. It was divided into 2 parts first, then each part was cut in half to make 4 equal parts.
Now look at Bar B. It also has 4 equal parts, but there's no middle step—it went straight to 4 parts.
What strategy created Bar B's 4 equal parts directly?

prompt.text: Select the strategy used for Bar B

options: Divide into 4 parts at once with evenly spaced lines
Divide into 3 parts first, then add one more
Start with 8 parts and combine them

step.dialogue: Look at Bar B again. How many lines divide it into 4 parts?

events.name: highlight_partition_lines
events.description: The 3 partition lines in Bar B pulse to emphasize even spacing

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_partition_lines]You're working on it. Bar B has 3 evenly spaced lines creating 4 parts all at once. No intermediate step like Bar A's middle line.

events.name: trace_intermediate_line
events.description: Animated annotation traces Bar A's middle line, showing the 2-step process

events.name: trace_all_lines_simultaneously
events.description: Animated annotation traces all 3 lines in Bar B at once, showing direct partitioning

step.dialogue: [event:trace_intermediate_line][event:trace_all_lines_simultaneously]Let's look at this together. Bar A used the 2-then-2 method—you can see that middle line. Bar B is different: it has 3 evenly spaced lines creating 4 equal parts directly, with no intermediate step. That's direct partitioning. See how that works?

on_correct.dialogue: Exactly right. Different strategies, same result—4 equal parts.

@metadata.goal: The student can understand that all parts must be equal for unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here are two bars. Both have 6 parts with 1 part shaded.
Look closely at how the parts are divided. Bar A has equal parts. Bar B has unequal parts.
Which statement is most accurate about these two bars?

options: Only Bar A shows 1/6; Bar B cannot represent a unit fraction
Neither can show a unit fraction

step.dialogue: Look at the size of each part in both bars.

events.name: highlight_sections
events.description: Bar A sections highlight in sequence to show equal sizing, then Bar B sections highlight in sequence to show unequal sizing

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_sections]Let's think about this together. For a fraction to work, all parts must be equal. Check which bar has equal parts.

events.name: measure_sections_equal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines confirming all sections in Bar A are equal width

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting size differences in Bar B sections

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_equal][event:measure_sections_unequal]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. For any fraction to exist, all parts must be exactly equal. Bar A has 6 equal parts, so 1 shaded part is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]. Bar B has unequal parts—see how some are bigger? That means Bar B can't represent a unit fraction. There we go.

on_correct.dialogue: Exactly right. Fractions only work when parts are equal—that's the foundation.
